recommendedCourses.description: We live in a world of numbers. You see them every day: on clocks, in the stock market, in sports, and all over the news. Algebra is all about figuring out the numbers you don't see. You might know how fast you can throw a ball, but can you use this number to determine how far you can throw it? You might keep track of stock prices, but how can you figure out how much money you've made (or lost) in the market? And you may already know how to tell time, but can you calculate at what times a clock's hour and minute hands are exactly aligned? With algebra, you can answer all of these questions, using the numbers you already know to solve for the unknown. Algebra is an essential tool for all of high school and college-level math, science, and engineering. So if you're starting out in one of these fields and you haven't yet mastered algebra, then this is the course for you! In this course, you'll be able to choose your own path within each lesson, and you can jump between lessons to quickly review earlier material. AlgebraX covers a standard curriculum in high school Algebra I, and CCSS (common core) alignment is indicated where applicable.Learn more about our High School and AP* Exam Preparation Courses Math

recommendedCourses.description: Learn about project management from a multidisciplinary perspective, as we cover fundamental tools and techniques for managing a broad range of projects.You will learn about the project management life cycle from initiation to closing. We will address the behavioral and quantitative facets of project management, as well as the use of methods, tools and techniques for the initiation, planning, execution and closing of projects. The course will be divided by the project life cycle phases.First, we will cover project initiation. We will review projects in organizations, project selection models, the project manager role and project organization structures to better understand how a project is initiated. You will also learn how to create a key project management deliverable, the project charter.Second, we will cover the project-planning phase. You will learn how to build a comprehensive project management plan covering the key aspects of risk, quality, scope, schedule, cost, time, resource and communications.Third, we will cover the project execution phase. We will explore the monitoring and control of a project including earned value analysis and project reporting. Case studies and examples will be used to help you understand the correct actions for a project manager to take to keep a project in control.
recommendedCourses.reason: Directly covers a core area of organizational management, focusing on concepts and terminology.

recommendedCourses.lessonTitle: Innovation Strategies for Electric Mobility: The StreetScooter Case
recommendedCourses.description: Learn about the tools and methods that can be employed to understand and identify customer needs as well as the processes that companies can set in place to foster and launch successful technological innovations. The theoretical knowledge will be transferred and applied to a recent, highly successful technological innovation from Germany: The StreetScooter, an electric delivery vehicle of Deutsche Post DHL. Specifically, the course will familiarize you with state-of-the-art tools, methods, and theories and help you understand how these may be used to solve and organize complex innovation challenges, placing a special emphasis on interdisciplinary thinking at the intersection of management and technology. recommendedCourses.description: We live in a world of numbers. You see them every day: on clocks, in the stock market, in sports, and all over the news. Algebra is all about figuring out the numbers you don't see. You might know how fast you can throw a ball, but can you use this number to determine how far you can throw it? You might keep track of stock prices, but how can you figure out how much money you've made (or lost) in the market? And you may already know how to tell time, but can you calculate at what times a clock's hour and minute hands are exactly aligned? With algebra, you can answer all of these questions, using the numbers you already know to solve for the unknown. Algebra is an essential tool for all of high school and college-level math, science, and engineering. So if you're starting out in one of these fields and you haven't yet mastered algebra, then this is the course for you! In this course, you'll be able to choose your own path within each lesson, and you can jump between lessons to quickly review earlier material. AlgebraX covers a standard curriculum in high school Algebra I, and CCSS (common core) alignment is indicated where applicable.Learn more about our High School and AP* Exam Preparation Courses Math

recommendedCourses.description: Linear regression is commonly used to quantify the relationship between two or more variables. It is also used to adjust for confounding. This course, part ofourProfessional Certificate Program in Data Science, covers how to implement linear regression and adjust for confounding in practice using R. In data science applications, it is very common to be interested in the relationship between two or more variables. The motivating case study we examine in this course relates to the data-driven approach used to construct baseball teams described in Moneyball. We will try to determine which measured outcomes best predict baseball runs by using linear regression. We will also examine confounding, where extraneous variables affect the relationship between two or more other variables, leading to spurious associations. Linear regression is a powerful technique for removing confounders, but it is not a magical process. It is essential to understand when it is appropriate to use, and this course will teach you when to apply this technique. Data Analysis & Statistics

recommendedCourses.description: We live in a world of numbers. You see them every day: on clocks, in the stock market, in sports, and all over the news. Algebra is all about figuring out the numbers you don't see. You might know how fast you can throw a ball, but can you use this number to determine how far you can throw it? You might keep track of stock prices, but how can you figure out how much money you've made (or lost) in the market? And you may already know how to tell time, but can you calculate at what times a clock's hour and minute hands are exactly aligned? With algebra, you can answer all of these questions, using the numbers you already know to solve for the unknown. Algebra is an essential tool for all of high school and college-level math, science, and engineering. recommendedCourses.description: LaTeX, a document preparation system, is widely used for publishing in many scientific fields like mathematics, statistics, computer science, engineering, chemistry, physics, economics, linguistics, etc.. It is a powerful and open-source system that provides numerous facilities for automating typesetting of the document: i.e. structuring page layout, listing and auto-numbering of sections, tables, figures, generating a table of contents, managing cross-referencing, citing, and indexing. Unlike other WYSIWYG editors, the content is written in plain text along with appropriate commands, thus, allowing the user to concentrate on the content rather than the aesthetics (the way it looks). The TeX typesetting program which LaTeX uses, was designed such that anyone can create good quality material with less efforts. This course introduces the basic concepts of LaTeX. Participants taking this course will be able to create and design documents in LaTeX and presentations in Beamer with confidence. Engineering

recommendedCourses.description: This course aims to teach everyone the basics of programming computers using Python. We cover the basics of how one constructs a program from a series of simple instructions in Python. The course has no pre-requisites and avoids all but the simplest mathematics. Anyone with moderate computer experience should be able to master the materials in this course. This course will cover Chapters 1-5 of the textbook "Python for Everybody". Once a student completes this course, they will be ready to take more advanced programming courses. This course covers Python 3. Computer Science

recommendedCourses.lessonTitle: Computing in Python I: Fundamentals and Procedural Programming
recommendedCourses.description: This course starts from the beginning, covering the basics of how a computer interprets lines of code; how to write programs, evaluate their output, and revise the code itself; how to work with variables and their changing values; and how to use mathematical, boolean, and relational operators. By the end of this course, you'll be able to write small programs in Python that use variables, mathematical operators, and logical operators. For example, you could write programs that carry out complex mathematical operations, like calculating the interest rate necessary to reach a savings goal, recommending apparel options based on weather patterns, or calculating a grade based on multiple percentages. Structurally, the course is comprised of several parts. Instruction is delivered via a series of short (2-3 minute) videos. In between those videos, you'll complete both multiple choice questions and coding problems to demonstrate your knowledge of the material that was just covered. Computer Science

weaknesses.weakness: Python string slicing 'stop' index misinterpretation
weaknesses.description: The student incorrectly includes the 'stop' index character when performing Python string slicing. Python's `[start:stop:step]` syntax extracts elements up to, but not including, the 'stop' index. The student's answer `bdf` indicates they included the character at index 5 ('f'), which is the 'stop' index, instead of stopping before it.

recommendedCourses.lessonTitle: Programming for Everybody (Getting Started with Python)
recommendedCourses.description: This course aims to teach everyone the basics of programming computers using Python. We cover the basics of how one constructs a program from a series of simple instructions in Python. The course has no pre-requisites and avoids all but the simplest mathematics. Anyone with moderate computer experience should be able to master the materials in this course. This course will cover Chapters 1-5 of the textbook "Python for Everybody". Once a student completes this course, they will be ready to take more advanced programming courses. This course covers Python 3. Computer Science
recommendedCourses.reason: Covers Python fundamentals including string slicing, directly addressing the underlying concept.

recommendedCourses.lessonTitle: Computing in Python I: Fundamentals and Procedural Programming
recommendedCourses.description: This course starts from the beginning, covering the basics of how a computer interprets lines of code; how to write programs, evaluate their output, and revise the code itself; how to work with variables and their changing values; and how to use mathematical, boolean, and relational operators. By the end of this course, you'll be able to write small programs in Python that use variables, mathematical operators, and logical operators. For example, you could write programs that carry out complex mathematical operations, like calculating the interest rate necessary to reach a savings goal, recommending apparel options based on weather patterns, or calculating a grade based on multiple percentages. Structurally, the course is comprised of several parts. Instruction is delivered via a series of short (2-3 minute) videos. In between those videos, you'll complete both multiple choice questions and coding problems to demonstrate your knowledge of the material that was just covered. Computer Science
recommendedCourses.reason: Focuses on Python fundamentals and procedural programming, which includes core string operations and indexing.

weaknesses.weakness: Difficulty with Deductive Reasoning and Quantifiers
weaknesses.description: The student struggles with logical inferences involving quantifiers like 'all' and 'some'. Errors show a tendency to overgeneralize 'some' to 'all' or incorrectly infer negative conclusions, indicating confusion about the precise scope and implications of these terms in syllogistic reasoning.

weaknesses.weakness: Inability to Recognize Geometric Progressions in Number Series
weaknesses.description: The student consistently fails to identify multiplicative patterns in numerical sequences. Instead of recognizing the 'multiply by 2' rule, they attempt various incorrect additive strategies or make inconsistent leaps, indicating a lack of familiarity with common series types, especially geometric progressions.

weaknesses.weakness: Misunderstanding of HTTPS and Secure Connections
weaknesses.description: The student lacks fundamental knowledge about what HTTPS signifies. Errors suggest confusion between encrypted connections and other unrelated website characteristics like public access, government affiliation, or speed, indicating a gap in basic internet security awareness.

weaknesses.weakness: Insufficient Knowledge of Strong Password Best Practices
weaknesses.description: The student demonstrates a poor understanding of what constitutes a strong password. Answers frequently include easily guessable personal information or overly simplistic character sets, indicating a need for education on creating robust and secure passwords.

weaknesses.weakness: Limited Understanding of Digital Literacy Scope
weaknesses.description: The student has a narrow or incorrect perception of digital literacy. They tend to equate it with specific technical skills (e.g., programming) or recreational activities (e.g., gaming) rather than its broader definition encompassing the safe and effective use of digital tools and information.

weaknesses.weakness: Failure to Identify Malicious Intent of Phishing
weaknesses.description: The student does not understand the primary objective of phishing attacks. They incorrectly associate phishing with positive or neutral IT functions, such as improving security or speeding up systems, indicating a critical gap in recognizing common cyber threats and deceptive tactics.

weaknesses.weakness: Misinterpretation of Logical OR Operator
weaknesses.description: The student struggles with basic propositional logic, specifically the truth conditions of the OR operator. When one operand is false and the compound statement 'A OR B' is true, they fail to correctly infer that the other operand 'B' must be true, often choosing 'Both' or 'False'.

weaknesses.weakness: Confusion Regarding Two-Factor Authentication Mechanisms
weaknesses.description: The student misunderstands how two-factor authentication (2FA) enhances security. They confuse it with using multiple passwords or unrelated security measures like encryption, indicating a lack of clarity on the concept of distinct verification factors beyond just a single password.

recommendedCourses.description: We live in a world of numbers. You see them every day: on clocks, in the stock market, in sports, and all over the news. Algebra is all about figuring out the numbers you don't see. You might know how fast you can throw a ball, but can you use this number to determine how far you can throw it? You might keep track of stock prices, but how can you figure out how much money you've made (or lost) in the market? And you may already know how to tell time, but can you calculate at what times a clock's hour and minute hands are exactly aligned? With algebra, you can answer all of these questions, using the numbers you already know to solve for the unknown. Algebra is an essential tool for all of high school and college-level math, science, and engineering. So if you're starting out in one of these fields and you haven't yet mastered algebra, then this is the course for you! In this course, you'll be able to choose your own path within each lesson, and you can jump between lessons to quickly review earlier material. weaknesses.weakness: Difficulty drawing correct inferences from categorical statements.
weaknesses.description: The student struggles with syllogistic reasoning, specifically when translating 'some' and 'all' statements into valid conclusions. Errors include overgeneralizing particular statements to universal ones or making invalid negative inferences, indicating a misunderstanding of the scope of quantified logical propositions.

weaknesses.weakness: Inability to identify multiplicative patterns in number sequences.
weaknesses.description: The student consistently fails to recognize multiplication as the underlying rule in numerical series. They may attempt additive patterns or make inconsistent jumps, suggesting a lack of systematic approach to identifying non-linear patterns in sequences.

weaknesses.weakness: Misunderstanding core concepts of digital security and online safety.
weaknesses.description: The student demonstrates a lack of foundational knowledge regarding common cybersecurity practices and threats. This includes misinterpreting the purpose of secure connections (HTTPS), the components of strong passwords, the malicious intent of phishing attacks, and the mechanism of two-factor authentication.

weaknesses.weakness: Narrow understanding of the concept of digital literacy.
weaknesses.description: The student misinterprets digital literacy as a limited set of specialized or recreational skills, rather than its broad definition encompassing the safe and effective use of digital tools for various purposes. They fail to grasp the comprehensive nature of digital competence in a modern context.

weaknesses.weakness: Confusion regarding the truth conditions of the logical OR operator.
weaknesses.description: The student struggles with applying the truth table for the logical OR operation, particularly in scenarios where one operand is known to be false. This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding of how the OR operator evaluates truth values and determines the overall truth of a compound statement.

recommendedCourses.description: We live in a world of numbers. You see them every day: on clocks, in the stock market, in sports, and all over the news. Algebra is all about figuring out the numbers you don't see. You might know how fast you can throw a ball, but can you use this number to determine how far you can throw it? You might keep track of stock prices, but how can you figure out how much money you've made (or lost) in the market? And you may already know how to tell time, but can you calculate at what times a clock's hour and minute hands are exactly aligned? With algebra, you can answer all of these questions, using the numbers you already know to solve for the unknown. Algebra is an essential tool for all of high school and college-level math, science, and engineering. So if you're starting out in one of these fields and you haven't yet mastered algebra, then this is the course for you! In this course, you'll be able to choose your own path within each lesson, and you can jump between lessons to quickly review earlier material. AlgebraX covers a standard curriculum in high school Algebra I, and CCSS (common core) alignment is indicated where applicable.Learn more about our High School and AP* Exam Preparation Courses Math
recommendedCourses.reason: Algebra is crucial for understanding and generalizing patterns, including geometric progressions (multiplicative sequences).

recommendedCourses.description: Planning to study for an MBA but unsure of your basic maths skills? All MBA programs, and in business generally require some maths, particularly on quantitative subjects such as Accounting, Economics and Finance.In this mathematics course, you will learn the fundamental business math skills needed to succeed in your MBA study and in the field of business. These math skills will also give you an edge in the workplace enabling you to apply greater analytical skill to your decision making.You will learn how to evaluate and manipulate the types of formulae that appear in an accounting syllabus, how to perform the calculus required to solve optimization problems in economics and how to apply the concept of geometric series to solving finance-related problems such as calculating compound interest payments.This course assumes no prior knowledge of business maths, concepts are explained clearly and regular activities give you the opportunity to practice your skills and improve your confidence. Business & Management

recommendedCourses.lessonTitle: Social Media: How Media Got Social
recommendedCourses.description: Social media and online communication dominate our daily lives in an unprecedented manner. Wireless connectivity, mobile devices and wearable technologies mean that social media is always on, always part of everyday life for billions of people across the world. While the term 'social media' is barely a decade old, the story of how people started using the internet in a social manner is a much longer and more interesting one. This course willincrease learners' understanding of social media by looking at the ways networked connectivity let users become 'social', how this was amplified with the emergence of the web, and how social media became the default mode of the mobile web we use today.By completing this course, you should be able to:  Communication

weaknesses.weakness: Deductive Reasoning with Quantifiers
weaknesses.description: The student struggles with logical inference, particularly when dealing with quantified statements (all, some, no). They frequently draw universal conclusions from particular premises or make incorrect negative inferences, indicating a misunderstanding of how quantifiers affect the validity of arguments.

weaknesses.weakness: Identifying Numerical Series Patterns
weaknesses.description: The student consistently fails to identify the underlying mathematical operation in a simple number series. They tend to apply incorrect arithmetic operations (e.g., adding a constant) instead of recognizing a multiplicative or exponential pattern.

weaknesses.weakness: Understanding HTTPS Security Protocol
weaknesses.description: The student misunderstands the primary function of HTTPS. They confuse it with general website attributes like public access, faster speed, or government affiliation, rather than recognizing its core purpose as indicating an encrypted and secure connection.

weaknesses.weakness: Password Security Best Practices
weaknesses.description: The student lacks knowledge regarding the essential components of a strong password. They incorrectly suggest easily guessable personal information or insufficient character types, indicating a gap in understanding modern password complexity and security requirements.

weaknesses.weakness: Broad Scope of Digital Literacy
weaknesses.description: The student holds a narrow or incorrect view of digital literacy, mistakenly equating it to specialized technical skills like programming or recreational activities like gaming. This indicates a failure to grasp the comprehensive nature of using digital tools safely, effectively, and responsibly.

weaknesses.weakness: Recognizing Malicious Intent of Phishing
weaknesses.description: The student fails to understand the malicious objective of phishing attempts. They incorrectly associate phishing with beneficial or neutral outcomes like improving security or speeding up systems, rather than its true aim of stealing sensitive information.

weaknesses.weakness: Propositional Logic: OR Operator Truth Conditions
weaknesses.description: The student demonstrates confusion regarding the truth conditions of the logical OR operator. They incorrectly deduce the truth value of a proposition within a disjunction, indicating a fundamental misunderstanding of truth tables and how the OR operator functions.

weaknesses.weakness: Understanding Two-Factor Authentication (2FA)
weaknesses.description: The student has a superficial or incorrect understanding of two-factor authentication. They mistake it for simply duplicating existing security measures like passwords or confuse it with other security concepts like encryption, rather than recognizing it as a distinct second layer of verification.

recommendedCourses.description: About the Database Series of Courses"Databases" was one of Stanford's three inaugural massive open online courses in the fall of 2011. It has been offered in synchronous and then in self-paced versions on a variety of platforms continuously since 2011. The material is now being offered as a set of five self-paced courses, which can be taken in a variety of ways to learn about different aspects of databases. Relational Databases and SQL is the most popular course in the Databases series. It is applicable to learners seeking to gain a strong understanding of relational databases, and to master SQL, the long-accepted standard query language for relational database systems. Additional courses focus on advanced concepts in relational databases and SQL, formal foundations and database design methodologies, and semistructured data.All of the courses are based around video lectures and demos. Many of them include quizzes between video segments to check understanding, in-depth standalone quizzes, and/or a variety of automatically-checked interactive exercises. Each course also includes an unmoderated discussion forum and pointers to readings and resources.
recommendedCourses.reason: Advanced SQL topics heavily rely on sophisticated deductive reasoning for complex queries, nested logic, and set operations, which are direct applications of quantifier concepts.

The material is now being offered as a set of five self-paced courses, which can be taken in a variety of ways to learn about different aspects of databases. Relational Databases and SQL is the most popular course in the Databases series. It is applicable to learners seeking to gain a strong understanding of relational databases, and to master SQL, the long-accepted standard query language for relational database systems. Additional courses focus on advanced concepts in relational databases and SQL, formal foundations and database design methodologies, and semistructured data.All of the courses are based around video lectures and demos. Many of them include quizzes between video segments to check understanding, in-depth standalone quizzes, and/or a variety of automatically-checked interactive exercises. Each course also includes an unmoderated discussion forum and pointers to readings and resources. The courses are described briefly below. Taught by Professor Jennifer Widom, the overall curriculum draws from Stanford's popular longstanding Databases course.
recommendedCourses.reason: SQL queries require precise deductive reasoning to construct logical conditions, and the language includes explicit quantifiers (e.g., EXISTS, ALL, ANY).

And you may already know how to tell time, but can you calculate at what times a clock's hour and minute hands are exactly aligned? With algebra, you can answer all of these questions, using the numbers you already know to solve for the unknown. Algebra is an essential tool for all of high school and college-level math, science, and engineering. So if you're starting out in one of these fields and you haven't yet mastered algebra, then this is the course for you! In this course, you'll be able to choose your own path within each lesson, and you can jump between lessons to quickly review earlier material. AlgebraX covers a standard curriculum in high school Algebra I, and CCSS (common core) alignment is indicated where applicable.Learn more about our High School and AP* Exam Preparation Courses Math
